questions.question_text: In a system using single processor, a new process arrives at the rate of six processes per minute and each such process requires seven seconds of service time. What is the CPU utilization?
questions.correct_answer_explanation: To find the CPU utilization, we can use the formula: CPU utilization = (arrival rate * service time) / 60. Given the arrival rate is 6 processes per minute and the service time is 7 seconds, we can calculate the CPU utilization as (6 * 7) / 60 = 0.7 or 70%.

questions.question_text: A CPU has a five-stage pipeline and runs at 1 GHz frequency. Instruction fetch happens in the first stage of the pipeline. A conditional branch instruction computes the target address and evaluates the condition in the third stage of the pipeline. The processor stops fetching new instructions following a conditional branch until the branch outcome is known. A program executes 10^9 instructions out of which 20% are conditional branches. If each instruction takes one cycle to complete on average, the total execution time of the program is:
questions.correct_answer_explanation: To find the total execution time, we need to consider the pipeline stalls caused by the conditional branches. Since 20% of the instructions are conditional branches, the number of branches is 0.2 * 10^9 = 2 * 10^8. Each branch causes a 2-cycle stall (since the branch is resolved in the 3rd stage), so the total stall time is 2 * 2 * 10^8 = 4 * 10^8 cycles. The total execution time is then (10^9 + 4 * 10^8) / 10^9 = 1.4 seconds.

questions.question_text: On receiving an interrupt from an I/O device, the CPU

options.option: Branches off to the interrupt service routine after completion of the current instruction
Branches off to the interrupt service routine immediately
Hands over control of address bus and data bus to the interrupting device

questions.correct_answer: Branches off to the interrupt service routine after completion of the current instruction
questions.correct_answer_explanation: When the CPU receives an interrupt from an I/O device, it will finish executing the current instruction and then branch off to the interrupt service routine to handle the interrupt.
